did.abstract: Correspondence, reports, legal records, financial documents and genealogical material of Roger Sherman, signer of the Declaration of Independence. Included are both family letters and political correspondence. Of special interest are the letters to Governor Jonathan Trumbull on the relationship of Connecticut to the prosecution of the war (1777-1780). Among Sherman's writings are a report from the Constitutional Convention (1787), a note on the proposal for a national bank (1791) and a printed copy of his Almanac for 1760. Genealogical and other papers assembled by Sherman's grandson, George Frisbie Hoar (1826-1904) are also in the collection. Major correspondents are Oliver Ellsworth, Samuel Hopkins, Titus Hosmer, Samuel Huntington, Stephen Mix Mitchell and William Williams.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Roger Sherman was born in 1721 in Newton, Massachusetts, and early moved to Stoughton, Massachusetts, where he attended the public schools and later learned the shoemaker's trade. He moved to New Milford, Connecticut, in 1743 and became surveyor of New Haven County in 1745. During this period Sherman was engaged in the study of law and was admitted to the bar in 1754. He was a member of the Connecticut Assembly in 1755, 1756, 1758-61 and 1764-66. As Justice of the Peace for Litchfield County (1755-1761), he issued the warrant for the arrest of Timothy Hurlburt. He served as judge of the New Haven Superior Court and was a member of the State Senate. He served as Treasurer of Yale College from 1765 to 1776. He was a member of the Continental Congress 1774-1781, 1783, and 1784, and signed the Declaration of Independence as a member of the committee which drafted it. He was also on the committee which drafted the Articles of Confederation, and a delegate to the Constitutional Convention of 1787. As such he became the only person to sign all the great American state papers: the Articles of Association, of 1774, the Declaration of Independence of 1776, the Articles of Confederation in 1783, and the Constitution in 1787.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, reports, legal records, financial documents and genealogical material of Roger Sherman, signer of the Declaration of Independence. Included are both family letters and political correspondence. Of special interest are the letters to Governor Jonathan Trumbull on the relationship of Connecticut to the prosecution of the war (1777-1780). Among Sherman's writings are a report from the Constitutional Convention (1787), a note on the proposal for a national bank (1791) and a printed copy of his Almanac for 1760. Genealogical and other papers assembled by Sherman's grandson, George Frisbie Hoar (1826-1904) are also in the collection. Major correspondents are Oliver Ellsworth, Samuel Hopkins, Titus Hosmer, Samuel Huntington, Stephen Mix Mitchell and William Williams.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Papers of Roger Sherman (1721-1793) are divided into two parts. The first consists of about two hundred items which were taken from the Baldwin Family Papers. Included here are correspondence for the years 1783-1793, financial records, and a survey map made by Roger Sherman in 1753. A folder list in this register provides an over-all guide to these materials. In addition, each item is individually catalogued in the Manuscripts and Archives catalogue under the heading, Roger Sherman, 1721-1793.

In 1975 Yale University Library acquired the second part, ninety items, as a gift from Charles H. W. Foster, Hugh K. Foster and Rockwood H. Foster. These comprise correspondence for the period 1770-1790, writings, including notes on the Constitution and on proposals for a national bank, a printed almanac compiled by Sherman in 1760, and materials on the Sherman family. An itemized list of these materials is in this register under the title, ROGER SHERMAN COLLECTION, ADDITION.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in four series: I. CORRESPONDENCE (1770-1790); II. WRITINGS (1760-1794); III. FINANCIAL AND LEGAL DOCUMENTS (1734-1792); and IV. GENEALOGICAL (1855-1904)
The correspondence is arranged alphabetically by writer. The other materials are arranged chronologically, and each item is fully described in the succeeding pages.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This addition of about ninety items to the Roger Sherman Collection comprises miscellaneous correspondence of Roger Sherman, writings and notes on the Constitution, on proposals for a national bank, a printed almanac compiled by Sherman in 1760, and materials on the Sherman family. These papers, as well as two family Bibles, were given in 1975 as a gift to Yale University Library by Charles H.W. Foster, Hugh Foster and Rockwood Foster. Because the collection includes not only papers contemporary with Roger Sherman, but also family letters and genealogical materials dating from the 19th and 20th centuries, the items have been arranged both by period and kind into four series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: ALS to Samuel Hopkins:, (1721-1803), discussing Hopkins' book, An Inquiry into the Nature of True Holiness (1773). Sherman defends "self-love" and questions Hopkins' proposition "that it is the duty of a person to be willing to give up his eternal interest for the Glory of God." 1790 Jun 28, New York. [6] p. and cover sheet marked, "Copy of a letter to the Revd. S. Hopkins June 1790."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: ALS to Roger Sherman, defending his views, declaring that self-love "can answer no good end,: and offering the idea of "universal benevolence" in its place. 1790 Aug 2, Newport. 15 p. in paper covers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: ALS to Samuel Hopkins replying to his letter of 1790 Aug 2, suggesting that Hopkins uses "the term selflove in a narrower sense than it is used in general by others." Sherman maintains that "our own temporal as well as spiritual good may be lawfully sought and enjoyed and our sensitive appetites gratified, so that it not be done in a manner or degree prohibited by law." 1790 October , [7] p. with verso of outer sheet marked "Copy of a Letter to the Revd. S. Hopkins. October 1790." Sewed together with letter of 1790 Jun 28.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
